subject: RE: [junit] Request for better questions
msgSnippet: It was graciously pointed out to me that my statement below gave the apperance that I was poking fun at those trying to learn, which on rereading seems like a
messageBody:
It was graciously pointed out to me that my statement below gave the
apperance that I was poking fun at those trying to learn, which on
rereading seems like a reasonable, although incorrect interpretation.

For anyone interested in clarification, just replace "stupidest" with
"laziest" below.

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Michael Silverstein [mailto:msilverstein@...]
> Sent: Monday, March 31, 2003 7:31 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: RE: [junit] Request for better questions
>
>
> An agreeable sentiment, but a waste of bytes because anyone
> who is going to ask the type of question you described is not
> going to bother looking through the history to find your post.
>
> You can at least have fun with it. We have a weekly
> "Stupidest JUnit question" contest at work. Most weeks
> there's an embarrasment of riches to choose from.
>
> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: J. B. Rainsberger [mailto:jbrains@...]
> > Sent: Sunday, March 30, 2003 9:20 PM
> > To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> > Subject: [junit] Request for better questions
> >
> >
> > Everyone:
> >
> > Before you ask a question like "How do I test XXX with
> > JUnit", please ask yourself the following question: how is
> > testing XXX different from testing a plain Java class? If you
> > cannot find a difference, then you have your answer. If you
> > find an answer, please describe your answer along with your
> question.
> >
> > Although we are here to help people learn to use JUnit
> > effectively, we are not here to be pro bono consultants.
> >
> > It's just a question of common courtesy.
> >
> > Thanks.
> >
> >
> > J. B. Rainsberger,
> > President, Diaspar Software Services
> > Let's write software that people understand.
> > http://www.diasparsoftware.com/
> > telephone: +1 416 791-8603
> >
> >
